title: 'Crimea is not only central to Ukraine-Russia conflict, but also risks dividing the US and Europe'
summary: Regardless of the Trump administration's talks on a possible ceasefire succeed, the Black Sea peninsula, annexed by Russia in 2014, remains at the heart of the conflict, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: Trump's 100 days: The case of Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a symbol of the historic reshaping of immigration
summary: The 29-year-old Salvadoran, a laborer in Maryland wrongfully deported and imprisoned in a Salvadoran prison, has become emblematic of Donald Trump's willingness to deport whomever he pleases.

title: US, Ukraine sign minerals deal, tying Trump to Kyiv
summary: Announcing the signing of the deal in Washington on Wednesday, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said it showed 'both sides' commitment to lasting peace and prosperity in Ukraine.'

title: In Syria, the challenge of reconstruction despite international sanctions
summary: As some cities have been largely destroyed during the war, residents have been attempting to resettle since the fall of Bashar al-Assad in December. Efforts have been hindered by a lack of investment.

title: Martin Scorsese to produce documentary chronicling the work of Pope Francis, 'Aldeas – A New Story'
summary: Aldeas Scholas Film and Scorsese's Sikelia Productions, in an announcement on Wednesday, said the film is 'a testament to the enduring belief that creativity is not only a means of expression but a path to hope and transformation.' Pope Francis died on April 21 at age 88. The filmmakers say this will serve as his final in-depth on-camera interview.

title: At the heart of Chanel's leather workshops near Paris
summary: In Verneuil-en-Halatte, 300 artisans are dedicated to crafting two of the fashion house's best-selling bags – a complex and precious expertise.

title: Inside the breast milk factory saving premature babies at Paris children's hospital
summary: Twelve thousand liters of milk from donors are collected and processed each year in the basement of Necker Hospital. How is this precious liquid obtained, treated and distributed? Le Monde visited the regional milk bank of the Paris region with its head, neonatologist, Virginie Rigourd.

title: Barcelona fight back against Inter Milan in semi-final draw
summary: The teams reached a thrilling 3-3 draw on Wednesday. The second leg takes place next Tuesday, with the winner to face Paris Saint-Germain or Arsenal on May 31 in the Munich final.

title: Trump says US kids may get '2 dolls instead of 30,' but insists China will suffer more in a trade war
summary: The president's remarks followed a defensive morning after the Commerce Department reported that the US economy shrank at an annual rate of 0.3% during the first quarter. Behind the decline was a surge in imports as companies tried to front-run the sweeping tariffs on autos, steel, aluminum in almost every country

title: 'Be cruel, have no pity on them': Taganrog prison, a notorious site of Russian torture
summary: In the Russian detention facility, Ukrainian prisoners, whether civilians or military, have been subjected to a range of abuses since the February 2022 invasion, from psychological humiliation to severe physical torture.

title: Steve Bannon on Trump's first 100 days: 'We want to make this revolution permanent'
summary: The former White House strategist turned podcaster breaks down, in an interview with Le Monde, the dynamics of Donald Trump's second term and the preparation that led up to his return to power.

title: Spain grid operator report had warned of blackout risk linked to renewables
summary: One of Europe's biggest ever power outages hit Spain and Portugal on Monday, cutting telephone and internet access, halting public transport and plunging cities into darkness. No firm cause for the blackout has yet emerged.

title: Airbnb's golden age is over in certain French cities
summary: In an effort to address the housing crisis, some cities such as Biarritz, in the southwest, have decided to impose much stricter rules on secondary residences and short-term rental owners.

title: Wildfires near Jerusalem prompt army deployment
summary: Rapidly spreading fires caused several injuries and prompted Defense Minister Israel Katz to declare the situation a 'national emergency.'

title: The regrets of three old crooks at the Kim Kardashian robbery trial
summary: Yunice Abbas, 71, Marc Boyer, 78, and Didier Dubreucq, 70, recounted their lives as 'street children.' Collectively, they have spent almost 60 years behind bars.

title: Cuba faces population decline and aging amid mass migration exodus
summary: Cuba's population fell below the 10 million mark in 2024. Independent experts fear a more pronounced demographic decline, driven by the exodus of the working population and a drop in birth rates on this island grappling with a deep economic crisis.

title: American economy on 'pause' as Trump's trade war looms
summary: The aggressive trade war launched by the US president threatens to trigger inflation and shortages of goods and plunge the country into recession.

title: Teenager perpetrator of fatal school stabbing in France says he was 'in a sort of lucid dream'
summary: The student who killed a classmate and injured three others in Nantes, western France, struggled to explain his actions to investigators. Visibly disturbed, he mentioned his relationship with one of his victims and the radical environmental manifesto he claimed to have written.

title: The marvelous bronzes of Angkor on display at the Musée Guimet in Paris
summary: For the first time, the immense reclining Vishnu statue from the Western Mebon, a national treasure of Cambodia, will be displayed with all its recovered fragments.

title: Georgia: Closure of the main independent television channel
summary: Mtavari TV is ceasing broadcasting on Thursday, May 1, amid increasing repression of the opposition by the pro-Russian governing party, Georgian Dream.

title: Matcha's popularity risks causing shortages
summary: The global supply of Japanese green tea powder is threatened by its social media-fueled popularity.

title: When diplomacy à la Trump repeatedly clashes with reality
summary: On three critical issues – Ukraine, Gaza and the Iranian nuclear program – the US president's proposals, pushed by an inexperienced adviser, have yielded little success at the start of his term.

title: A Palestinian student at Columbia has been released after his arrest during a US citizenship interview
summary: Since the first days of the Trump administration, immigration authorities have arrested and detained college students from around the country, many of whom participated in campus protests. Mohsen Mahdawi is among the first of those students to win his freedom: 'I am not afraid of you,' he said, addressing Donald Trump and his Cabinet.

title: The first hundred days of Trump: 'In Kentucky, I heard little about a weakening of democratic value'
summary: In an op-ed, American sociologist Arlie Russell Hochschild shares insights from her interviews with residents of a rural and impoverished district in this US state, where 80% of voters supported Trump in 2024.

title: The extraordinary destiny of war and celebrity photographer Germaine Kanova
summary: Colette, Romain Gary, Audrey Hepburn, but also Churchill and de Gaulle… Kanova was both a photographer of celebrities and a fearless war reporter. Fifty years after her death, this long-forgotten figure is finally reemerging, as her rich archives resurface in a book and two exhibitions.

title: World's oldest person, a Brazilian nun, has died at the age of 116
summary: Inah Canabarro Lucas attributed her longevity to God and to her religious order. The esteemed title now passes to Ethel Caterham of Surrey, England, age 115.

title: In the Highlands, bedrooms fit for lords
summary: In Scotland's wildest region, a famous Swiss gallery-owning couple, Iwan and Manuela Wirth, have restored the noble Fife Arms to its former glory. This 19th-century Victorian-style hotel is adorned with artworks from their collection.

title: Tesla sales in France plummet further, down 59% in April
summary: After first-quarter data from a European body showed Tesla sales had dropped 45% across Europe, a French report has added weight to analyses linking Elon Musk's political activities to his company's flagging sales.

title: Lily of the valley: When an Internatonal Workers' Day tradition in France 'becomes bourgeois'
summary: Over 1 million French households purchased lily of the valley flowers in 2024, a volume that's declining over several years. The flower, linked to International Workers' Day, is still produced in western France, but now mainly comes from Hamburg, observes Le Monde's Laurence Girard.

title: Rare earths: China's fearsome weapon in the trade war with Donald Trump
summary: The Chinese government has implemented export controls on seven strategic rare earth metals, over which China holds a near-monopoly and thus controls the supply chain.

title: War in Ukraine: Zelensky urges pressure on Russia after drone strikes on cities
summary: After an overnight strike, conducted using 170 drones, on cities such as Odesa, Kyiv, Sumy and Kropyvnytskyi, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky called for sanctions to pressure Russia and force it to negotiate.

title: Transgender women barred from women's football by English and Scottish Football Associations
summary: These new rulings will apply to all women's football at amateur and professional levels in both countries.

title: Kamala Harris criticizes Trump's vision of the US
summary: In her first major post-election speech, former US vice president Kamala Harris slammed President Donald Trump, saying he was undertaking 'the wholesale abandonment' American ideals.

title: Musk loses much (but not all) by working with Trump
summary: By deciding on drastic federal spending cuts and promoting his opinions bordering on the far right, the billionaire has compromised his reputation and fortune.

title: At International Court of Justice, a week of testimonies on Israel's legal obligations for aid to Gaza
summary: The humanitarian blockade on aid for Gaza over the past two months and Israeli obstructions to the UN agency for Palestinian refugees were debated at the international court. The judges' opinion is expected soon, though it might go unheeded.
